questions.text: Watering from the eyes of an infant occurs in all of the following except
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Corneal dystrophy Watering from the eyes of an infant can occur due to a variety of conditions affecting the tear drainage system or ocular surface. The correct answer is (D) Corneal dystrophy, as this condition is not typically associated with excessive tearing in infants. Corneal dystrophy refers to a group of inherited disorders that affect the cornea, leading to clouding, scarring, or other structural changes. These conditions usually manifest later in life and are not commonly associated with epiphora (watering of the eyes) in infants. The primary symptoms of corneal dystrophy include visual impairment or photophobia, but tearing is not a hallmark feature. Incorrect Options: (A) Congenital dacryocystitis Congenital dacryocystitis occurs due to an obstruction in the nasolacrimal duct, which prevents normal drainage of tears. This leads to persistent tearing, crusting, and sometimes infection. Watering is a characteristic symptom of this condition, making this option incorrect. (B) Buphthalmos Buphthalmos is an enlargement of the eye caused by congenital glaucoma. Elevated intraocular pressure (IOP) leads to corneal edema and irritation, which stimulates reflex tearing. This condition commonly presents with symptoms like excessive tearing, photophobia, and corneal haze in infants. Thus, watering is a key feature, making this option incorrect. (C) Corneal foreign body A corneal foreign body irritates the corneal surface, triggering the lacrimal glands to produce excess tears as a reflex response. This is a protective mechanism of the eye to flush out the foreign object. Therefore, corneal foreign bodies are associated with watering of the eyes, making this option incorrect.

questions.text: Mother of 3 months old infant complains of watering from one eye. On pressing the lacrimal sac, there is regurgitation of mucopurulent material. The appropriate treatment is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Lacrimal sac massage and antibiotics. The condition described in the question is most likely congenital nasolacrimal duct obstruction (CNLDO), which is common in infants. It occurs due to a failure of the nasolacrimal duct to open at birth, leading to tear retention, watering, and sometimes mucopurulent discharge upon pressing the lacrimal sac. Initial treatment for CNLDO involves conservative management. Gentle massage of the lacrimal sac (also known as Crigler’s massage) helps to open the obstruction and encourage drainage. Topical antibiotics are prescribed if there is a mucopurulent discharge to address any secondary infection. This approach is effective in the majority of cases during the first year of life, as spontaneous resolution often occurs. Incorrect Options: (A) DCR (Dacryocystorhinostomy) DCR is a surgical procedure used to create a new drainage pathway from the lacrimal sac into the nasal cavity. This is not appropriate in infants because the condition usually resolves with conservative measures. DCR is reserved for older children or adults with persistent or complicated cases. (B) Probing Probing of the nasolacrimal duct is considered the next step if conservative management fails. It is generally performed after the age of 6-12 months, as spontaneous resolution is still possible in younger infants. Probing is not the first-line treatment for a 3-month-old. (C) Probing with syringing Probing with syringing is a more invasive procedure used to confirm patency after probing the nasolacrimal duct. This step is unnecessary at the initial stage and is performed only if initial probing fails or if there is a more complex obstruction.

questions.text: Most common organism causing chronic dacryocystitis is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Staphylococcus aureus. Chronic dacryocystitis is a condition characterized by chronic inflammation and infection of the lacrimal sac, often due to obstruction of the nasolacrimal duct. The most common causative organism is Staphylococcus aureus, although other organisms may also be involved. Staphylococcus aureus is the most frequently isolated organism in chronic dacryocystitis. It is a gram-positive bacterium known for causing persistent infections in various tissues, including the lacrimal system. Chronic infections often develop because of the blocked drainage pathway, which creates a favorable environment for bacterial growth. Incorrect Options: (B) Pseudomonas aeruginosa (Pseudo pyocyanea) Pseudomonas is a gram-negative bacterium commonly associated with acute infections, particularly in immunocompromised patients. It is not the most common cause of chronic dacryocystitis but can occasionally be isolated in some cases. (C) Streptococcus haemolyticus Streptococcus species, including hemolytic types, are known to cause a range of infections. While they can be involved in dacryocystitis, they are not the most common organisms in chronic cases. (D) Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Mycotuberculosis) Tubercular dacryocystitis is extremely rare and is usually associated with systemic tuberculosis. It can present as a granulomatous form of dacryocystitis but is not a common cause of chronic dacryocystitis.

questions.text: Most common tumor of lacrimal gland is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Benign mixed tumor. The most common tumor of the lacrimal gland is a pleomorphic adenoma, which is also referred to as a benign mixed tumor. It is the most frequent neoplasm in this location, typically presenting as a painless, slow-growing mass in the superotemporal orbit. Benign mixed tumors, or pleomorphic adenomas, account for the majority of lacrimal gland tumors. These are benign epithelial tumors composed of epithelial and mesenchymal components. They are slow-growing, well-encapsulated, and present with progressive proptosis and a painless mass in the lacrimal gland region. Surgical excision is curative in most cases, provided complete removal is achieved to prevent recurrence. Incorrect Options: (A) Adenoid cystic carcinoma Adenoid cystic carcinoma is the most common malignant tumor of the lacrimal gland, not the most common tumor overall. It is aggressive, painful, and often associated with perineural invasion, which can lead to a poor prognosis. (B) Adenocarcinoma Adenocarcinoma is a rare malignant tumor of the lacrimal gland. It is not as common as benign mixed tumors or adenoid cystic carcinoma. (D) Mucoepidermoid carcinoma Mucoepidermoid carcinoma is an extremely rare malignant tumor of the lacrimal gland. It is not as common as pleomorphic adenomas or adenoid cystic carcinoma.

questions.text: In DCR operation, opening in nose is made in:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Middle meatus. In a dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR) operation, the goal is to create a new drainage pathway between the lacrimal sac and the nasal cavity. The opening is made in the middle meatus, which is anatomically the most appropriate location for draining tears into the nasal cavity. The middle meatus is the part of the nasal cavity beneath the middle turbinate. This area is ideal for creating an opening during DCR because the lacrimal sac lies adjacent to this region. By connecting the lacrimal sac to the middle meatus, tear drainage is effectively restored, bypassing the obstruction in the nasolacrimal duct. Incorrect Options: (A) Superior meatus The superior meatus is located beneath the superior turbinate and is involved in the drainage of the posterior ethmoidal sinuses. It is not anatomically related to the lacrimal sac and is not used in DCR surgery. (B) Inferior meatus The inferior meatus is located beneath the inferior turbinate and is the natural drainage site for the nasolacrimal duct. However, in cases of nasolacrimal duct obstruction, the DCR bypasses this natural pathway, creating a new opening in the middle meatus instead. (D) Superior turbinate The superior turbinate is a bony structure in the nasal cavity associated with the superior meatus. It is not involved in the anatomy of the lacrimal drainage system and is irrelevant to DCR surgery.

questions.text: Valve at the entry of the common canaliculus:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Valve of Rosenmuller. The valve at the entry of the common canaliculus into the lacrimal sac is the valve of Rosenmuller. It plays a role in regulating the flow of tears and preventing reflux from the lacrimal sac. The valve of Rosenmuller is a mucosal fold located at the junction where the common canaliculus enters the lacrimal sac. It acts as a functional valve, preventing the backflow of tears from the sac into the canaliculi. This is important for the proper functioning of the lacrimal drainage system. Incorrect Options: (A) Valve of Hasner The valve of Hasner, also known as the plica lacrimalis, is located at the distal end of the nasolacrimal duct where it opens into the inferior meatus of the nose. It prevents nasal secretions from entering the nasolacrimal duct but is not located at the entry of the common canaliculus. (C) Both While both valves exist within the lacrimal drainage system, the valve of Rosenmuller specifically refers to the entry of the common canaliculus, not the valve of Hasner. (D) None This option is incorrect because the valve of Rosenmuller is indeed present at the entry of the common canaliculus.

Correct Answer (A) Greater superficial petrosal nerve. The secretion of tears is primarily controlled by parasympathetic innervation to the lacrimal gland, which is supplied by the greater superficial petrosal nerve, a branch of the facial nerve. The greater superficial petrosal nerve arises from the facial nerve and carries preganglionic parasympathetic fibers. These fibers synapse in the pterygopalatine ganglion, and the postganglionic parasympathetic fibers travel via branches of the maxillary nerve (zygomatic nerve and lacrimal nerve) to innervate the lacrimal gland, stimulating tear secretion. Incorrect Options: (B) Facial nerve While the facial nerve gives rise to the greater superficial petrosal nerve, it does not directly supply the lacrimal gland. The role of the facial nerve is upstream in the pathway of tear secretion. (C) Deep petrosal nerve The deep petrosal nerve carries sympathetic fibers from the superior cervical ganglion. While sympathetic fibers may contribute to the modulation of lacrimal gland function, they are not primarily responsible for tear secretion. (D) Maxillary nerve The maxillary nerve (a branch of the trigeminal nerve) carries the postganglionic parasympathetic fibers to the lacrimal gland via its branches (zygomatic and lacrimal nerves).

Correct Answer (D) Malignancy of the lacrimal sac. Dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR) is a surgical procedure typically performed to bypass an obstructed nasolacrimal duct and restore normal tear drainage. However, DCR is contraindicated in the presence of malignancy of the lacrimal sac, as the surgery would not address the underlying cancer, and the malignancy may require a different treatment approach. DCR is contraindicated in cases where malignancy, such as a lacrimal sac carcinoma, is present. In such cases, surgery to remove the cancerous tissue would be more appropriate than DCR. Performing DCR in the presence of malignancy could inadvertently spread cancer cells or not resolve the primary disease. Incorrect Options: (A) Mucocoele A mucocoele is a cystic lesion filled with mucus that typically occurs in the lacrimal sac due to obstruction of the nasolacrimal duct. DCR can be performed in such cases to relieve the obstruction and allow drainage, making this option incorrect. (B) Chronic dacryocystitis Chronic dacryocystitis, caused by long-standing obstruction of the nasolacrimal duct, is a common indication for DCR. The procedure helps to bypass the blocked duct and alleviate symptoms of chronic infection, making this option incorrect. (C) NLD obstruction (Nasolacrimal duct obstruction) Nasolacrimal duct obstruction (NLD obstruction) is one of the most common indications for DCR. The procedure is designed to relieve obstruction and restore proper tear drainage, so this option is incorrect.

questions.text: Distance of Angular vein from medial canthus as it passes over medial palpebral ligament is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) 8mm. The angular vein is located near the medial canthus and passes over the medial palpebral ligament. The typical distance of the angular vein from the medial canthus as it traverses the medial palpebral ligament is about 8mm. The angular vein is an important venous structure in the medial region of the eye and is responsible for draining blood from the medial part of the eyelids and the nose. As it passes over the medial palpebral ligament, it is approximately 8mm away from the medial canthus, which is a standard anatomical distance for this vein. Incorrect Options: (A) 6mm This is not the typical distance for the angular vein. The angular vein lies slightly further away from the medial canthus, typically around 8mm, making this option incorrect. (B) 10mm While the angular vein may vary slightly between individuals, 10mm is generally considered too far from the medial canthus. The standard anatomical distance is closer to 8mm. (D) 12mm A distance of 12mm is also too far for the angular vein as it passes over the medial palpebral ligament. The typical distance is closer to 8mm, making this option incorrect.

choices.text: Normal BUT is more than 10 secs
Jones dye test is used for dry eye

questions.text: Which of the following is false:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Jones dye test is used for dry eye. This statement is false because the Jones dye test is primarily used to evaluate the patency of the nasolacrimal drainage system, not to diagnose dry eye. The Jones dye test involves the instillation of fluorescein dye into the eye, followed by observation to check for the presence of the dye in the nose, which helps determine if the nasolacrimal duct is patent. This test is not used for diagnosing dry eye, which involves evaluating tear production and ocular surface condition. Incorrect (True) Options: (A) Normal BUT is more than 10 secs The Break-up Time (BUT) is the time it takes for the tear film to break up after a blink. A normal BUT is generally more than 10 seconds. A shorter BUT can indicate dry eye or insufficient tear production. Thus, this statement is true. (C) Rose Bengal stains dead cells Rose Bengal is a vital stain used to highlight damaged or dead epithelial cells on the ocular surface. It stains the dead or devitalized cells and is commonly used to assess the condition of the cornea and conjunctiva, particularly in dry eye syndrome. This statement is true. (D) Acetylcysteine dissolves mucus Acetylcysteine is a mucolytic agent that helps break down and dissolve thick mucus. It is commonly used in conditions where mucus accumulation is problematic, such as in respiratory disorders or certain eye conditions like chronic conjunctivitis. This statement is true.

questions.text: Ideal time for syringing and probing is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) 1 year. Syringing and probing of the nasolacrimal duct (NLD) are typically performed to treat congenital nasolacrimal duct obstruction (CNLDO), which is common in infants. The ideal time for performing syringing and probing is generally around 1 year of age. By the age of 1 year, many cases of CNLDO do not resolve spontaneously, and syringing or probing is often recommended if conservative measures (such as lacrimal sac massage) have failed. The success rate for probing is high when done around this age, as the duct is still relatively soft, and the risk of complications is low. Incorrect Options: (A) 2-3 months At 2-3 months, the nasolacrimal duct obstruction is often still resolving on its own. Probing is usually not performed this early, as many infants show spontaneous resolution by this age, and treatment is conservative (e.g., massage) during this period. (B) 4-6 months While probing may be considered if the obstruction persists at 4-6 months, the ideal time is typically closer to 1 year. This period allows for further observation of spontaneous resolution, and probing is usually recommended if the condition continues beyond this time. (D) 5 years By the age of 5 years, the child has usually either had the obstruction treated earlier or spontaneously resolved it. Probing and syringing are not typically performed at this age unless the condition is persistent and severe, which is relatively uncommon.

choices.text: Upper puncta is medial to lower puncta
Lower puncta is medial to upper puncta

questions.text: The alignment of lower and upper puncta are:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Upper puncta is medial to lower puncta. The upper punctum (located on the upper eyelid) is positioned slightly medial (toward the nose) to the lower punctum (located on the lower eyelid). This alignment is typical in most individuals. The alignment of the puncta refers to the small openings in the eyelids where tears drain into the lacrimal system. The upper punctum is situated closer to the nose than the lower punctum, which lies slightly lateral to the upper punctum. This anatomical relationship helps facilitate the normal drainage of tears from the eye into the nasolacrimal duct. Incorrect Options: (B) Lower puncta is medial to upper puncta This is incorrect because, as mentioned above, the upper punctum is located medially to the lower punctum in the typical anatomical arrangement. (C) They superimpose each other The upper and lower puncta do not superimpose; they are aligned with a slight medial-lateral relationship, with the upper punctum being slightly medial to the lower punctum. (D) None of the above This option is incorrect because option (A) correctly describes the typical anatomical alignment of the puncta.

questions.text: The density of goblet cells are maximum in
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Nasal conjunctiva. Goblet cells, which secrete mucus to help maintain a stable tear film and protect the ocular surface, are found in the conjunctiva. The nasal conjunctiva has the highest density of goblet cells compared to other areas of the conjunctiva. The nasal conjunctiva (the part of the conjunctiva near the nose) has the maximum density of goblet cells. These cells secrete mucus, which helps to form a stable tear film and keep the ocular surface moist. Goblet cell density decreases as you move toward the temporal, superior, and inferior conjunctival regions. Incorrect Options: (B) Temporal conjunctiva The temporal conjunctiva, located towards the outer part of the eye (near the temples), has fewer goblet cells compared to the nasal conjunctiva. The density of goblet cells is generally lower in the temporal region. (C) Superior conjunctiva The superior conjunctiva (on the upper eyelid) also contains goblet cells, but its density is lower than in the nasal conjunctiva. Goblet cells are more concentrated in the areas of the conjunctiva that are in direct contact with the tear film. (D) Inferior conjunctiva The inferior conjunctiva (on the lower eyelid) has a moderate concentration of goblet cells, but again, it is not as dense as in the nasal conjunctiva.

questions.text: NLD opens in the inferior meatus
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Anteriorly. The nasolacrimal duct (NLD) opens into the inferior meatus of the nasal cavity anteriorly, near the area where the nasal floor meets the lower part of the nasal cavity. This is where tears drain from the lacrimal sac into the nose. The nasolacrimal duct opens into the inferior meatus of the nasal cavity anteriorly. This location is critical for the normal drainage of tears from the eye into the nasal cavity, where they are eventually reabsorbed or cleared. Incorrect Options: (B) Posteriorly The NLD does not open posteriorly into the inferior meatus. The opening is at the anterior portion of the inferior meatus, not toward the back of the nasal cavity. (C) Medially The NLD opens anteriorly into the inferior meatus, not medially. Medial positioning would be closer to the septum, which is not where the NLD drains. (D) Laterally The NLD does not open laterally into the inferior meatus. The opening is anterior and near the nasal floor, not on the lateral side.

questions.text: A 44-year-old woman comes to the physician because of pain and swelling below her left eye for 3 days. She has also had excessive watering from her eyes during this period. She has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Examination shows erythema, tenderness, warmth, and swelling below the medial canthus of the left eye. There is purulent discharge from the lower lacrimal punctum on palpation of the swelling. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. The discharge is sent for cultures. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Acute dacryocystitis is most commonly caused by gram-positive cocci (staphylococci, streptococci). Oral antibiotics with gram-positive coverage, such as amoxicillin-clavulanate, would be the first-line empirical therapy in a patient with mild to moderate acute dacryocystitis. As this patient has no features of severe infection, i.e., fever or features of orbital cellulitis (restricted, painful eye movement or diplopia), oral antibiotics are an appropriate treatment option. Warm compresses and NSAIDs are also used to decrease pain and inflammation.

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl comes in to the emergency department with her mother for swelling of her left periorbital region. Yesterday morning she woke up with a painful, warm, soft lump on her left eyelid. Eye movement does not worsen the pain. Physical examination shows redness and swelling of the upper left eyelid, involving the hair follicles. Upon palpation, the swelling drains purulent fluid. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) A hordeolum is an acute purulent inflammation of the eyelid, most commonly due to Staphylococcus aureus, that comes in two forms. An external hordeolum or stye, as seen in this patient, arises from the glands of Moll or glands of Zeis. An internal hordeolum (less common) is an inflammation of a meibomian gland, most typically at the palpebral conjunctiva. The appearance of an acute painful, erythematous, and purulent nodule can be worrying to patients, but the condition typically resolves after 1–2 weeks.

questions.text: A 19-year-old girl comes to her physician with blurred vision upon awakening for 3 months. When she wakes up in the morning, both eyelids are irritated, sore, and covered with a dry crust. Her symptoms improve after she takes a hot shower. She is otherwise healthy and takes no medications. She does not wear contact lenses. Her temperature is 37.4°C (99.3°F), and pulse is 88/minute. Both eyes show erythema and irritation at the superior lid margin, and there are flakes at the base of the lashes. There is no discharge. Visual acuity is 6/6 bilaterally. Which of the following is the next best step in management?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Warm compresses, lid massage, and gentle lid cleansing are the cornerstones of therapy for mild blepharitis, as seen in this patient. As blepharitis is often a chronic condition with discrete episodes, ongoing lid hygiene is important in minimizing the frequency and intensity of flares. Oral doxycycline can be used in the treatment of severe or treatment-refractory blepharitis. It is not used as first-line treatment, especially for a mild presentation such as this one, because of the risk of adverse events, such as photosensitivity, gastrointestinal distress, and interference with oral contraceptives.
